articles.headline: Amazon Pauses Work on 2nd Headquarters in Virginia
articles.snippet: The delay is the latest reminder that the tech industry’s pandemic-fueled boom has slowed and another indicator of how remote work has changed office-space needs.
articles.abstract: The delay is the latest reminder that the tech industry’s pandemic-fueled boom has slowed and another indicator of how remote work has changed office-space needs.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Amazon said in 2018 that it planned to build a second headquarters in Virginia, along with a sister office complex in New York, it was a symbolic moment for the tech industry’s increasing importance to the American economy.
articles.byline: By Karen Weise and Lora Kelley

articles.headline: The Democrats’ SOS Candidate Keeps His Options Open
articles.snippet: Gov. J.B. Pritzker of Illinois has maintained his political organization, built a progressive record and is open about his ambitions. For now, he says, they don’t include the White House.
articles.abstract: Gov. J.B. Pritzker of Illinois has maintained his political organization, built a progressive record and is open about his ambitions. For now, he says, they don’t include the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Gov. J.B. Pritzker of Illinois sat comfortably in an office board room high above the Loop on Monday and halfheartedly batted away the notion that he was preparing a run for the White House.

articles.headline: Conservative Media Pay Little Attention to Revelations About Fox News
articles.snippet: Even in today’s highly partisan media world, experts said, the lack of coverage about the private comments of Fox’s top executives and hosts stands out.
articles.abstract: Even in today’s highly partisan media world, experts said, the lack of coverage about the private comments of Fox’s top executives and hosts stands out.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fox News and its sister network, Fox Business, have avoided the story. Newsmax and One America News, Fox’s rivals on the right, have steered clear, too. So have a constellation of right-wing websites and podcasts.
articles.byline: By Katie Robertson and Stuart A. Thompson

articles.headline: Biden Meets With German Chancellor Amid Concerns Over Ukraine and China
articles.snippet: President Biden said he and Germany’s chancellor, Olaf Scholz, would work in “lock step” to provide military support to Ukraine.
articles.abstract: President Biden said he and Germany’s chancellor, Olaf Scholz, would work in “lock step” to provide military support to Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden and Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany on Friday showed a united front on the war in Ukraine, vowing to keep Western support intact amid mounting concerns that China could move to supply weapons to Moscow.

articles.headline: Is the Entire Economy Gentrifying?
articles.snippet: Companies are trying to maintain fat profits as the economy changes, making “premiumization” their new favorite buzzword.
articles.abstract: Companies are trying to maintain fat profits as the economy changes, making “premiumization” their new favorite buzzword.
articles.lead_paragraph: Big companies are prodding their customers toward fancier, and often pricier, versions of everything from Krispy Kreme doughnuts to cans of WD-40.
articles.byline: By Jason Karaian and Jeanna Smialek

articles.headline: How the Fall of Roe Turned North Carolina Into an Abortion Destination
articles.snippet: The state, which is near others with abortion bans and restrictions, has had a 37 percent rise in abortions since the constitutional right to abortion was overturned.
articles.abstract: The state, which is near others with abortion bans and restrictions, has had a 37 percent rise in abortions since the constitutional right to abortion was overturned.
articles.lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — Clinic by clinic, county by county and up to the highest levels of state government, no state embodies the nation’s post-Roe upheaval like North Carolina.

articles.headline: A New Front Line in the Debate Over Policing: A Forest Near Atlanta
articles.snippet: Six weeks after a protester was shot and killed, officials are bracing for more confrontations with activists seeking to stop a police and fire training center.
articles.abstract: Six weeks after a protester was shot and killed, officials are bracing for more confrontations with activists seeking to stop a police and fire training center.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — When construction crews rolled into a patch of pine and maple trees southeast of Atlanta last month, the scene had more in common with a military incursion than a municipal building project in the suburbs. Police officers in armored trucks escorted construction workers as they cleared a pathway for heavy equipment and installed anti-erosion fences.
articles.byline: By Sean Keenan and Joseph Goldstein

articles.headline: Whirring Into Action in Ukraine’s Skies
articles.snippet: Against the odds, Ukraine’s helicopter brigades are not only still operational, but are an inspirational component of its war effort.
articles.abstract: Against the odds, Ukraine’s helicopter brigades are not only still operational, but are an inspirational component of its war effort.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a snowbound field, three Soviet-era helicopters were being readied for battle. Pilots and crew checked the flight plan for their next target, while technicians loaded slim gray rockets into launcher pods and stacked flares into racks behind the exhaust.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and Daniel Berehulak

articles.headline: Eyeing DeSantis, Trump Readies for a Long Primary Battle
articles.snippet: Donald Trump basked in affection from activists at CPAC on Saturday. But his campaign is preparing for an ugly, protracted primary fight for the nomination — and pledging even an indictment would not stop him.
articles.abstract: Donald Trump basked in affection from activists at CPAC on Saturday. But his campaign is preparing for an ugly, protracted primary fight for the nomination — and pledging even an indictment would not stop him.
articles.lead_paragraph: OXON HILL, Md. — Inside the MAGA-clad corridors of this week’s Conservative Political Action Conference, the politics of the Republican Party seemed almost unchanged from the pinnacle of Donald J. Trump’s presidency. Sequin-wearing superfans jostled for selfies with whichever member of the Trump family happened to be nearby. Chants of “We love Trump!” rang out in the halls.
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher, Michael C. Bender and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Inside the Panic at Fox News After the 2020 Election
articles.snippet: “If we hadn’t called Arizona,” said Suzanne Scott, the network’s chief executive, according to a recording reviewed by The New York Times, “our ratings would have been bigger.”
articles.abstract: “If we hadn’t called Arizona,” said Suzanne Scott, the network’s chief executive, according to a recording reviewed by The New York Times, “our ratings would have been bigger.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A little more than a week after television networks called the 2020 presidential election for Joseph R. Biden Jr., top executives and anchors at Fox News held an after-action meeting to figure out how they had messed up.

articles.headline: Heads Up: A Better Movie Seat May Cost You
articles.snippet: As the film business changes rapidly, multiplexes are experimenting with prices in ways that may seem shocking to theatergoers.
articles.abstract: As the film business changes rapidly, multiplexes are experimenting with prices in ways that may seem shocking to theatergoers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Anyone buying a ticket for a concert, baseball game, Broadway play or flight has experienced it: Seats are now priced with dizzying complexity, with costs in some instances changing minute by minute, based on demand.

articles.headline: Using A.I. to Detect Breast Cancer That Doctors Miss
articles.snippet: Hungary has become a major testing ground for A.I. software to spot cancer, as doctors debate whether the technology will replace them in medical jobs.
articles.abstract: Hungary has become a major testing ground for A.I. software to spot cancer, as doctors debate whether the technology will replace them in medical jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Inside a dark room at Bács-Kiskun County Hospital outside Budapest, Dr. Éva Ambrózay, a radiologist with more than two decades of experience, peered at a computer monitor showing a patient’s mammogram.
articles.byline: By Adam Satariano, Cade Metz and Akos Stiller For The New York Times

articles.headline: They’re Exporting Billions in Arms. Just Not to Ukraine.
articles.snippet: As traditional weapons suppliers like the U.S. face wartime production shortages, South Korea has stepped in to fill the gap, while trying not to provoke Moscow.
articles.abstract: As traditional weapons suppliers like the U.S. face wartime production shortages, South Korea has stepped in to fill the gap, while trying not to provoke Moscow.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHANGWON, South Korea — A year after Russia invaded Ukraine, the war has spurred a global effort to produce more missiles, tanks, artillery shells and other munitions. And few countries have moved as quickly as South Korea to increase output.

articles.headline: In Florida Legislative Session, a Chance for DeSantis to Check Off His Wish List
articles.snippet: Republican lawmakers have indicated the session will be guided by Gov. Ron DeSantis’s priorities, including a proposal that would expand gun rights.
articles.abstract: Republican lawmakers have indicated the session will be guided by Gov. Ron DeSantis’s priorities, including a proposal that would expand gun rights.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida has made it his political mission to, as he likes to say, put points on the board.

articles.headline: You’re Now a ‘Manager.’ Forget About Overtime Pay.
articles.snippet: New evidence shows that many employers are mislabeling rank-and-file workers as managers to avoid paying them overtime.
articles.abstract: New evidence shows that many employers are mislabeling rank-and-file workers as managers to avoid paying them overtime.
articles.lead_paragraph: For four years beginning in 2014, Tiffany Palliser worked at Panera Bread in South Florida, making salads and operating the register for shifts that began at 5 a.m. and often ran late into the afternoon.

articles.headline: Ukrainian Soldiers, Nearly Encircled, Push Russians Back
articles.snippet: The battle for Bakhmut is not over — at least not yet. Ukrainian assault brigades offered Moscow a bloody reminder of that over the weekend.
articles.abstract: The battle for Bakhmut is not over — at least not yet. Ukrainian assault brigades offered Moscow a bloody reminder of that over the weekend.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHASIV YAR, Ukraine — Lined up in the dark in civilian vehicles, lights dimmed, a company of soldiers waited silently at the side of a road. Farther behind, a second company was parked, an occasional light inside a car revealing the face of a soldier. Still farther back, a third company was moving into place.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and Daniel Berehulak

articles.headline: Republican Votes Helped Washington Pile Up Debt
articles.snippet: As they escalate a debt-limit standoff, House Republicans blame President Biden’s spending bills for an increase in deficits. Voting records show otherwise.
articles.abstract: As they escalate a debt-limit standoff, House Republicans blame President Biden’s spending bills for an increase in deficits. Voting records show otherwise.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden will submit his latest budget request to Congress on Thursday, offering what his administration says will be $2 trillion in plans to reduce deficits and future growth of the national debt.

articles.headline: A Gen Z Mystery: My Instagram Posts Keep Showing Up on Facebook!
articles.snippet: Teenagers and young adults are flummoxed. The reason it keeps happening involves an online prompt and product design.
articles.abstract: Teenagers and young adults are flummoxed. The reason it keeps happening involves an online prompt and product design.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than a decade ago, Qu’ana Underwood, then a middle school student in Philadelphia, joined Facebook. But as other social media platforms appeared, Facebook “became an afterthought,” she said.
articles.byline: By Kalley Huang and Sheera Frenkel
